entry.title: Binding a SAC Custom Widget to Multiple Models Simultaneously
entry.content:
Is it possible to connect a custom widget to more than one model at the same time? I'm developing a custom widget that compares data across models, and it would be highly beneficial to retrieve data directly from these models. Currently, I've implemented a workaround by passing data from hidden tables, each connected to a separate model.

According to the announcement post from 2022:

The keys of the dataBindings property represent the arbitrary name of the dataBinding, and contains a "feeds" property which is an array of objects that define a "feed". Currently this is limited to defining one dataBinding object. Defining multiples will not yield any error but only the first one will be used.

As far as I can tell, this limitation still applies. Are there any plans to support multiple dataBindings in the future?

Cheers,
Łukasz

entry.title: Re: SAP ABAP RAP - Missing value on UI after data created
entry.content:
Hi @yoppie_aries 

In unmanaged RAP, after persisting your new record, you must fill the result table that SAP UI5 consumes.

as an example :

APPEND VALUE #( %cid         = booking_data-%cid
                booking_id   = <your created ID>
                travel_id    = <your travel ID>
                customer_id  = <your customer>
                ... other fields ...
              ) TO result.

please make sure all necessary fields are filled. Otherwise, UI will not show the created data even though it exists in DB.

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Open Connectors
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Open Connectors

In today’s fast-paced digital landscape, seamless integration across various systems and applications is crucial for business success. SAP Open Connectors, a key capability within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), is designed to simplify and accelerate this process.

SAP Open Connectors offers a unified API integration layer that streamlines connectivity to over 160 third-party cloud applications, including popular platforms like Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics, Google services, and more.

Instead of building and maintaining individual connectors for each application, Open Connectors provides prebuilt connectors with standardized APIs, helping developers avoid the complexity of dealing with diverse authentication methods, pagination formats, error handling, and data models.

Assign Roles in BTP

  • OpenConnectorsAdmin
  • OpenConnectorsUser
  • OpenConnectorsDeveloper

 

 

Prerequisites:

  • SAP BTP account (Open Connectors supports trial accounts)

Demonstrate on how to connect Gmail API Connector

Firstly, Add the capabilities for Open Connectors on the Integration Suite. After that, we should assign the role related to Open Connectors.

Step 1: Integration suite Home page >> Capabilities >> Manage Capabilities. Click on “Manage Capabilities”.

Step 2: Click on “Add Capabilities”

Step 3: Click on check box i.e., Extend Non-Sap Connectivity

Step 4: After the above step, you will see the below mentioned in Home Page. Click on “Create Connectors”. After this step, you will be navigate to Open Connectors Home Page.

Open Connectors Configuration

Now, we will be working on Gmail Connector. After navigating to Open Connectors Home Page. You will be able to see the below page. Just, Search for the Gmail in search box.  

Connectors >> Gmail >> My Resources (place the cursor in Gmail connector, then only you can see the Resources) >> Authenticate Instance.

I am creating an instance with the name of “DemoGmail”.

After this step, you will be redirected to a different page or click this url 

  • https://console.cloud.google.com/

    Get Gmail OAuth Credentials 

    • Create a new project or use existing
    • Click on "Select a project".

      Give Project Name as Your wish. e.g. My Project - 1 >> Click on "Create".In the search bar, type Gmail API >> Click on Gmail API >> Click Enable.

      After enabling your API, you will be redirect to another page.

      This Step: Create OAuth Client Credentials

      Click on Create Credentials

      Click on "Configure consent screen".

      Click on "Get Started" which is highlighted in blue color.

      Give all the details

      App name: Test

      User support email: "Give your mail id e.g. xxxx@gmail.com"

      Choose "External"

      Contact Information: Give your mail id

      Click "Agree" checkbox >> Continue >> Create

      When you have this page, click on "Create OAuth client".

      Fill the details as mentioned in below Image.

      Skip "Authorized JavaScript origins"

      In "Authorized redirect URIs", Click "Add URI" >> give the urI as mentioned in below image >> Click on "Create". 

      Download your credentials by clicking on Download JSON or else you can copy & paste in your notepad. Click on OK.

      Go to Hamburger button which is located on Top Left side. You can see API & Services as shown in below image. click on it.

      API & Services >> Credentials >> Audience >> Add Users (add your mail id) >> click on "Save".

       Data Access >> Add or remove scopes >> add below scopes >> add to table >> click on update.

      https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.send

      https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.readonly

      https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.modify

      Navigate to your open connectors, give your client credentials, create instance.

      You will see the below page with success popup.

      Click on Test in the API docs

      GET: Retrieves data or resources from the server (ex: fetch mail messages). Follow the below images highlighted with red rectangle. 

      When you're complete your execution, if no errors you will get 200 message.

entry.title: Re: Session 2 Recap & Highlights– Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott
entry.content:
Thank you for this session. It helps clarify what a data product is.

One important foundational topic that is going to get even more important in the future is for clients to get the  organisation design in ERP right. In the past a lot of clients implemented ECC with 'custom' use of key fields such as business area, profit center, or perhaps having unusual use cases for accounts and cost centers. Just this week, there was a post in the group about a client looking at using business area for something which should be a profit center.

With all the effort to provide this semantic data in reporting, I think clients should want to stick to standard usage of fields even more than before.

I appreciate the example of Company Code, I took a look on api.sap.com and saw there were several key finance fields already there: leger, profit center, cost center, account etc. It's useful to be able to browse the JSON

https://api.sap.com/dataproduct/sap-s4com-CompanyCode-v1/overview

During the presentation I tried to capture informal notes on Irfan's summary of the architecture and the development/consumption flow. Perhaps I can check my understanding?

So for the hierarchy, I sketched out the below. Our 'golden source of truth' is the HANA DB, which feeds CDS views which then feed the data product in DataSphere. The data product gets all the annotations from the CDS views, but possibly may have more added during it's design?

 

And in terms of the flow of design, deploy and consume, I sketched it out like the below:

  1. We start with the basic data design which really comes from CDS design then data product design
  2. Then we have the push pipeline which is really two steps, extract from ERP, then replication to BDC datalake
  3. Then it's fully managed ongoing (presumably triggered by events in ERP etc.)
  4. Then it's ready to be consumed by apps / reports etc.

Loving the direction of 'open approach' and also the goal to eliminate ETL effort.

On the topic of data quality. I do think there isn't enough focus on helping clients get their data model right at the point of design/implementation of ERP. There are still clients and consultants citing incorrect definitions of basic fields every day. I think the problem is, it's not particularly exciting, but definitely an area that still needs focus.

My first ever role back 2000 was cleaning 120,000 vendors for an R/2 to R/3 migration! So fun.

entry.title: Designing a Fiori-Ready CDS View with UI Facets, Value Helps, and Associations in RAP
entry.content:
Introduction 

In this blog post, I will explain how to design a CDS view entity in ABAP RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) that is well-suited for use with Fiori Elements. We'll use annotations such as ui.facet, Consumption.valueHelpDefinition, ObjectModel.association, and search.defaultSearchElement to enhance the user interface and behavior.

The example is based on a Flight Management scenario, where we create a CDS view to manage flight connections and set up associations to carrier and flight-related data.

Use Case

  • Display flight connection details as the header, along with the related flight entries as line items

  • Provide value help functionality for airport-related fields

  • Use associations to link the CDS view to related entities such as carrier and airport information

  • Enable search capabilities and ensure the data is optimized for Fiori Elements

CDS View Entity Code 

ZPS_FLIGHT_R - Flight Information 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight Information' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_FLIGHT_R 
as select from /dmo/flight 
association[1] to ZPS_CARRIER_R as _Airline on $projection.CarrierId = _Airline.CarrierId  
{ 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10 }] 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Airline' 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20 }] 
key connection_id as ConnectionId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30 }] 
key flight_date as FlightDate, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40 }] 
@Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'CurrencyCode' 
price as Price, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50 }] 
currency_code as CurrencyCode, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
plane_type_id as PlaneTypeId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 70 }] 
seats_max as SeatsMax, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 80 }] 
seats_occupied as SeatsOccupied, 
_Airline 
}

ZPS_CARRIER_R - Carrier detail 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Carrier detail' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_CARRIER_R 
as select from /dmo/carrier 
{ 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Semantics.text: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.8 
name as Name, 
currency_code as CurrencyCode 
}

ZPS_AIRPORT_VH - Value help for airport 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Value help for airport' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_AIRPORT_VH 
as select from /dmo/airport 
{ 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key airport_id as AirportId, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
name as Name, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
city as City, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
country as Country 
}

ZPS_CONNECTION_FLIGHT - Flight Reference 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight Reference' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@UI.headerInfo: { 
typeName: 'Connection', 
typeNamePlural: 'Connections' 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_CONNECTION_FLIGHT 
as select from /dmo/connection as connection 
association [1..*] to ZPS_FLIGHT_R as _flight on $projection.CarrierId = _flight.CarrierId 
and $projection.ConnectionId = _flight.ConnectionId 
association [1] to ZPS_CARRIER_R as _Airline on $projection.CarrierId = _Airline.CarrierId 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{ id: 'Connection', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE, 
position: 10, 
label: 'Connection Detail' }, 
{ id: 'Flight', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
type: #LINEITEM_REFERENCE, 
position: 20, 
label: 'Flights', 
targetElement: '_flight' 
} 
] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 10, label: 'Airline' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Airline' }] 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Airline' 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 20 }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 20 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key connection_id as ConnectionId, 
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10 }] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 30, label: 'Depature Airport Id' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Depature Airport Id' }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity:{ 
name: 'ZPS_AIRPORT_VH', 
element: 'AirportId'} }] 
airport_from_id as AirportFromId, 
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20 }] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 40 }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 40 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity:{ 
name: 'ZPS_AIRPORT_VH', 
element: 'AirportId'} }] 
@EndUserText.label: 'Destination Airport ID' 
airport_to_id as AirportToId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 50, label: 'Departure Time' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 50 }] 
departure_time as DepartureTime, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 60, label: 'Arrival Time' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 60 }] 
arrival_time as ArrivalTime, 
@Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'DistanceUnit' 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 70 }] 
distance as Distance, 
distance_unit as DistanceUnit, 
//Association--> 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
_flight, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
_Airline 

}

Key Concepts Covered

Annotations
ui.facet : Creates grouped sections in the Fiori Object Page
ui.lineItem : Controls the display of fields in table lists
Consumption.valueHelpDefinit : Enables F4 value help for fields
search.defaultSearchElement : Makes the field available in the Fiori search bar
ObjectModel.text.association : Provides text description for key fields
Association to entity Enables : navigation and linking to related entities

You’ll see: 

  • A header section labeled "Connection Detail" displaying the main connection information

  • A "Flights" section or tab, enabled through the _flight association, showing related flight entries as line items

  • F4 help (value help) activated for airport_from_id and airport_to_id fields using @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition

  • A search bar that allows filtering by fields such as Airline, Connection ID, Departure Airport, and Destination Airport

     

Departure airport value help

Line-item record

Summary 

This blog demonstrated how to build a Fiori-optimized CDS view using ABAP RAP, with the help of UI annotations, value helps, and text associations.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Central Finance
entry.content:
Hello @Lena_Schmidt 

Thanks for your message.

Please note that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not support SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation) replication as either a source or target system. The S4 HANA public cloud architecture does not allow database-level access or trigger-based replication, which SLT requires via the LTRC transaction. This limitation includes Central Finance (CFIN) scenarios where SLT is typically used to replicate transactional data.

For data integration with S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP only supports communication via standard APIs (SOAP, OData) or event-based messaging using technologies like SAP Cloud Integration or Event Mesh. These are the officially supported and secure channels for connecting external systems.

If your use case depends on SLT or Central Finance, S/4HANA Public Cloud is currently not a suitable deployment model.
Please check this SAP help documentation Integration Guides Overview 

Let me know if you need further support

entry.title: Settlement of Investment Projects in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
What is Project Settlement?

Settlement is the process of transferring costs incurred on a project to a final receiver such as:

  • an asset under construction
  • a completed fixed asset
  • or a cost object (e.g. cost center)

In the context of capital investment projects, this ensures the capital expenditures (CapEx) are properly posted to the balance sheet instead of the P&L.

To start with a simplified view, we can split the complete process into two parts:

Asset Creation Phase

  • settlement moves costs from the investment project to asset(s) under construction

  • this can be done via periodic settlement at the close of the period or event-based with every posting to the investment project

Final Asset available to be used

  • settlement moves balance sheet values from asset(s) under construction to final asset 
    values that cannot be capitalised can be moved to other cost objects, e.g. cost centers

  • this is done via periodic settlement at the close of the period

 

Master Data Involved

Investment Projects are used primarily for planning and monitoring capital investments that are not capitalised directly, due to their scope or the large percentage of in-house production involved.

  • All expenditures related to the investment project are tracked separately to differentiate them from regular operational costs.
    This can include materials, labor, and overheads.
  • The account assignment object for actual posting is always the investment project/ WBS element.
  • Investment projects are relevant for asset accounting this is why they have an asset under construction (AuC) assigned.

Assets Under Construction refer to the work-in-progress phase where a company is finalising the development or acquisition of long-term assets (like a building or a piece of machinery).

  • Costs related to the asset under construction are recorded in an asset under construction/ capital work-in-process account on the balance sheet. This account accumulates all expenditures until the asset is ready for its intended use.
  • The asset under construction is included in the asset history sheet and keeps detailed records of all costs related to investment projects for audit and regulatory purposes.
  • Once the construction is completed and the asset is ready for use, the total accumulated costs in the asset under construction account are transferred to the appropriate fixed asset account on the balance sheet.

 

Lifecycle of the Investment Project

SAP provides standard capabilities to manage the entire lifecycle of an investment project:

  1. Project Creation
    initiated via the app Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  2. Cost Collection
    Costs from procurement, time recording, and service are collected on the investment project WBS (work breakdown structure) elements
  3. Asset Under Construction (AuC) Creation
    Automatically created when the project is released. Make sure you are using the project profile Investment Project.
  4. Periodic or Event-Based Settlement
    Periodic jobs can be scheduled via the app Schedule Overhead Accounting Jobs. For processing of single investment projects, you can use Run Settlement – Actual.
    With release CE2508 a new functionality Event-based Settlement to AuC is available. Using event-based settlement makes the periodic settlement process obsolete as all costs are settled immediately when posted to the investment project.
  5. Final Settlement and Asset Capitalisation
    Upon project completion, costs are settled to the final fixed asset. Costs that cannot be capitalised can be settled to other cost objects (e.g. cost centers).

 

How Project Settlement Works

1. Settlement to Asset under Construction (AuC)
  • periodic settlement: with the first settlement the rule to AuC gets automatically created (settlement type AUC)
    PRE rules can be used to make sure non-capitalisable costs are not posted to the AuC.
  • event-based settlement: 100% of the costs will be settled to AuC, rules for preliminary settlement (PRE rules) are not supported, no AUC settlement rule is needed.
    Event-based settlement is a new functionality made available with CE2508. It can be activated in the investment profile (for details on configuration see dedicated chapter).

2. Settlement to Final Asset

When the project is completed and the asset can be used, the AuC is cleared and costs are capitalised to the final asset.

  • The status of the investment project will be changed to technically completed. With this status the system carries out full settlement (distribution rules of type “full settlement” are used)
  • in the event-based scenario the final settlement will post to final receiver per line item, enabling the feature “list of origins reporting” for the AuC and the final asset
  • the processing type “partial capitalisation” can be used for a partial settlement to fixed asset/ other cost object, before the investment project is technically completed.

 

Settlement Rules

Define the receivers which could be AuC, final asset, or other cost objects.
Rules can be defined as percentages/ equivalences or amounts. Each rule comes with a validity period.

  • Full Settlement (FUL)
    • all costs posted to the sender, also costs in prior periods are settled
    • ensures a balance of zero even if late postings to prior period occur
    • these rules are used for final settlements to the fixed asset,
      or they can be used for partial capitalisation if values shall be moved out of the asset under construction before the asset is finished
  • Preliminary Settlement (PRE)
    PRE rules are used during settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement), if part of the costs shall not be activated on AuC
    > not available with event-based settlement
  • Settlement to AuC (AUC)
    with periodic settlement these rules are automatically created with the first settlement, the receiver is the AuC

Examples for different settlement/ distribution rules:

line 1 shows a rule for settlement from AuC to cost object that can be used with processing type “Partial Capitalisation”
such rules need to be valid for one period only (from/to = identical)

line 2 +3 show rules for settlement to fixed asset (final settlement)

line 4 shows a rule for settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement)
> not supported with event-based settlement

 

Period End Closing - Settlement Run

 

Event Based Settlement (new CE2508)

 

Ledger Specific Settlement Rules

  •  Ledger-Specific Settlement                                                 
    • values to be settled will be calculated per ledger 
    • always active in SAP Cloud ERP  
  • Ledger-Specific Settlement Rules
    • settlement rules can be defined per ledger
    • optional, needs to be activated in settlement profile

Possible Use Case
Settlements to assets under construction/ final asset shall be done according to different GAAPs, e.g. German GAAP defines that 70% of construction costs can be activated while US-GAAP allows for activation of 80% of construction costs.

 

Key Configuration Elements

  • Project Profile
    Project profiles are pre-delivered in the public cloud edition and cannot be configured. make sure you are using profile Investment Project to enable the integration to asset management
  • Settlement Profile
    Determines whether the settlement is allowed and to which receiver type.
  • Asset Class & Number Ranges
    Defines the type of asset created (e.g. building, machinery).
  • Investment Profile
    Used to configure the asset class for the asset under construction. You can also define if you want to have just one AuC created per WBS element, or if you need several AuC for one WBS element.
    The option for event-based settlement is also activated in the investment profile.

 

Benefits of Project Settlement in SAP Cloud ERP

  • Transparency: Clearly track investment costs and their capitalisation status
  • Automation: Reduce manual tasks with predefined rules and scheduled jobs
  • Compliance: Aligns with IFRS and local GAAP requirements
  • Audit Readiness: Comprehensive documentation of all postings and asset movements

Additional Benefits with Event-Based Settlements

  • Transparency: with event-based settlement postings are moved line item by line item throughout the complete settlement process from the project to the AuC and to the final asset.
  • Automation: as the first settlement step “Project 2 AuC” is done event-based, no manual interaction or job scheduling is needed any longer
  • Compliance: the line item details will still be available for the final asset. With this level of detail it is very easy to explain the asset value as for each posting can navigated back to the initial project posting. This kind of reporting is even available without using line item settlement.

entry.title: EWM Queue Error “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document"
entry.content:
In this blog, queues which are failed due to error message "Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document" will be resolved with step by step approach.

Issue Overview:

An Inbound Delivery is created without a batch number for a material which is maintained as batch-managed in material master.
Upon saving the delivery, its status changes to “B” (Distributed).As a result, an EWM inbound queue error occurs with the message:

“Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header.”

Steps to replicate the Issue:

Step 1:
Check in.material master to confirm that the material is batch-managed.

 

Step2:

The Inbound delivery as displayed in the below screenshot is created without batch

 

Step3:

On Saving the delivery, header status - Dec Whse for the delivery is changed to “B” (Distributed).

 

The EWM Error queue error occurs with the message as “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document Header”

 

 

Solution to resolve the EWM Queue:

Step1:

To resolve this , intial step is to save the queue with error using the transaction code SMQ2.

 

Step2:

From transaction code SE37, execute FM (Function Module) :  /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS

 

Once executed - this will reset the delivery’s distribution status from "B" (Distributed) to "A" (Relevant).

 

 

 

 

 Step3:

Delivery is now open and can be changes - hence a new batch can be created or assigned for the line items in the inbound delivery.

 

Step4:

Once completed - save S4 inbound delivery to  re-trigger the distribution to EWM, with updated batch information included, to process queues sucessfully.

 

Conclusion:

Provided  solution resolves EWM queue error “Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header” by resetting the distribution status, maintaining batch data, and successfully re-distributing the delivery to EWM.

entry.title: Re: Standard Exception Types for a Custom Reuseable Eleme...
entry.content:
You're correct that within Key User Extensibility (e.g., in Custom Business Objects (CBOs), Custom Logic, or the Cloud ABAP Environment), the RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE statement is permitted. However, the available exception classes are restricted to a safe, whitelisted set provided by SAP.

In the Key User extensibility framework (like in the method YY1_MARITIME_EXPERIENCE=>VOYAGE_ID_DERIVE), the most commonly allowed standard exception classes include:

1. CX_NO_CHECK

  • Root class for exceptions without explicit RAISING declaration.

  • You can inherit from this to create your own custom exceptions (if supported).

2. CX_STATIC_CHECK

  • For exceptions that must be declared in the method signature.

  • Less frequently usable directly unless a method signature explicitly supports it.

3. CX_DYNAMIC_CHECK

  • Runtime-check exceptions (can be raised dynamically).

But in Key User Extensibility, you may not be able to use all of these freely—SAP allows only a restricted subset, and you usually cannot define your own global exception classes .

entry.title: Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU
entry.content:
Steps to perform for Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU

Step 1:
Navigate to “Stock Data Transfer” in the SAP Easy Access menu or directly enter the transaction code /N/SCWM/ISU.

 

 

Step 2:
The Stock Data Transfer screen will appear.
Enter Warehouse Number, and click on the folder icon to select input file.

 

 

Step 3:
Navigate to the upload file as displayed in the screenshot, and select on the Upload button to upload data.

Prompt with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box will be displayed, check “Remember My Decision” and click “Allow” .

 

Step 4:
Uploaded data will be displayed in the highlighted section.

Click the Execute button to process the stock upload.

 

Step 5:
A Warehouse Task will be automatically created for the uploaded stock.

 

 

Step 6:
To verify the uploaded material and quantity, go to transaction /N/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor).

 

Step 7:
In the background, movement type 561 is triggered to post the stock into the ERP system.
You can verify this posting in transaction MB51.

 

Conclusion:

Steps to perform Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU is provided.

entry.title: Navigating the BP transaction Authorizations in S/4HANA : SAP Security Experts Guide
entry.content:
General Overview

The Business Partner (BP) transaction is the central tool for managing customer and vendor master data in SAP S/4HANA. For many customers, this represents a transition from older transactions like XK01, FK01, and FD01. This change is part of the core data model redesign in S/4HANA, aimed at consolidating customer and vendor information into a single, unified repository. By doing so, it eliminates data redundancy and streamlines business processes. This approach is often also referred to as Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI).

This shift has many SAP Security consultants scratching their heads. The consolidated transaction called BP in S/4HANA combines functionality from over 60 legacy transactions into one powerful master transaction. While efficient, This simplification introduces a lot of complexity — particularly for security.

When you check the SU24 data for the BP transaction, you'll find it can include anywhere from 20 to 80 authorization objects. While this extensive list provides fine-grained control over access—which is great from a security standpoint—it can also be overwhelming. Assigning the BP transaction to a PFCG role often means suddenly facing the task of maintaining values for 30 or more authorization objects, which few enjoy dealing with.

Another challenge with the BP transaction is that, despite having a large number of authorization objects available to control access, many of these checks are inactive by default. As a result, the transaction appears to offer granular control, but in reality, it lacks many essential authorization checks—making it difficult to enforce precise access restrictions.

If your organization has a central team managing master data, you may not encounter some of the challenges mentioned earlier. However, in scenarios involving geographically distributed teams and decentralized master data management, maintaining effective authorizations for the BP transaction can become a significant issue.

Now that we’ve identified the challenges, let’s explore how to tackle them. In this blog, I’ll clarify and break down the key authorization objects you can use to manage BP authorizations more effectively.

What all transactions BP replaced

Lets start with the basics, the following transaction codes are no longer available as standalone transactions in the S/4HANA system. You can verify the updated list by checking the PRGN_CORR2 table using transaction SE16 in your system.

  • FD01, FD02, FD03, FD05, FD06, FD08
  • FK01, FK02, FK03, FK05, FK06, FK08
  • MAP1, MAP2, MAP3
  • MK01, MK02, MK03, MK05, MK06, MK12, MK18, MK19
  • V-03, V-04, V-05, V-06, V-07, V-08, V-09, V-11, V+21, V+22, V+23
  • VAP1, VAP2, VAP3
  • VD01, VD02, VD03, VD05, VD06
  • XD01, XD02, XD03, XD05, XD06, XD07
  • XK01, XK02, XK03, XK05, XK06, XK07

It’s important to note that while you may still assign these transactions to users, executing them in S/4HANA typically redirects the user to the BP transaction, often accompanied by an informational message at the bottom of the screen "Redirecting to transaction BP"

 

Managing the Authorizations for Business Partner transaction

Just like restricting any other transaction in SAP, restricting BP transactions comes down to the correct restrictions across various authorization objects. We will go through these one by one. Lets start then,

When you Execute the BP transaction you are shown this initial screen(see figure) where you can search for a Business Partner(Customer, Vendor etc) using various criterias.

  • ✅ As expected an initial S_TCODE - checks for start transaction code access happens here. Nothing complicated so far,

Once you select a Business Partner the details of the business partner id displayed(see figure), and a lot of authorization checks happens at this level, this is where things gets complicated as well. Lets look at these one by one :

  • ✅ B_BUPA_RLT Business Partner: BP Roles

This Authorization object controls what BP role a uses has, these BP Role (don't confuse these with PFCG roles) defines what functions a user can perform (ACTVT) and also controls the assignment blocks visible in the BP screen(RLTYP). For example:- If the user selects "Business Partner(Gen.)" Role from the dropdown, it allows editing of basic(general) data of the BP. But if the users switches to a different role "Customer" then some additional tabs will open up where data relevant to cutomers can be maintained.

Although, SAP Delivers some standard BP roles these can still be configured and created in SPRO img configuration by your functional team if need arises.

SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Business Partner Roles →Define BP Roles

Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416144

Next is,

  • ✅ B_BUPA_GRP Business Partner: Authorization Groups

With this authorization object, you define which business partners can be edited on the basis of the authorization groups. Now this authorization is optional and You therefore do not have to assign this authorization if there is no master data requiring special protection.

This groups restrictions require 3 things to work properly -

  1. SPRO configuration which can be done here : SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings →Authorization Management -> Maintain Authorization Groups
  2. The group needs to be maintained in master data , this can be done via opening the Business partner in general role, Navigate to the Control tab of the BP screen, then maintaining the Authorization Group here. (see screenshot below)
  3. Include authorization object in the role assinged to the user with restrictions. Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416153

Next,

Based on whether you have opened Customer or Vendor different set of authorization will be checked.

  • For Customer - F_KNA1* authorization objects will be checked.
  • For Vendors - F_LFA1* authorization objects will be checked.

✅ F_KNA1_GEN/ F_LFA1_GEN - This authorization object controls which activities are permitted for the general data. The general data consists of the fields that are independent of the company code and the sales organization. This only has single authorization field for ACTVT

 
✅ F_KNA1_GRP/ F_LFA1_GRP - You use this authorization object to specify which activities are permitted for the individual account groups. The object consists of the "Activity" and "Account Group" fields. Note that this groups is different from the group in - B_BUPA_GRP.
 

 ✅ F_KNA1_APP/ F_LFA1_APP - You use this authorization object to determine which activities are allowed for customer/Vendor master records. The object is defined with the fields "Activity" and "Application authorization".

For all of these F_* authorization objects, You will get suggestion and pressing "F1" on the authorization objects will give you some help. These authorizations objects are well known adn documented.

Other Important Authorization objects

Apart from the major objects mentioned above, some of the other important objects are mentioned below. Most of these can be configured at location - SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Authorization Management

 

  • ✅ B_BUPA_ATT - This authorization object is optional and is typically used to restrict users to entering only specific values for certain fields. For Example: Suppose a user should only be allowed to create Business Partners with the country set to India. In this case, you can use this authorization object to ensure the user can only enter "IN" in the country field. Any attempt to use a different country code would be blocked based on this restriction. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416118/E
  • ✅ B_BUPA_FDG = Authorization object B_BUPA_FDG on BP is used exclusively for field level customization. The user can enforce authorization on the fields in the BP screen. The user for example can set a particular field on the screen as display only even in the change mode for the business partner. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416138/E
  • ✅ B_CCARD = You can use this object to regulate authorization for display and/or maintenance of payment card master data.
  • ✅ B_CCSEC = Use this authorization object to define who can display unmasked credit card numbers and who can evaluate or delete the access logs.
 
Some other authorization objects which control the Sales area and Company code level details of Business Partners are - V_KNA1_VKO, M_LFM1_EKO, F_KNA1_BUK, F_LFA1_BUK etc.

 

Miscelleneous

If you are still struggling with restricting access properly for BP transaction, You may find some of the below helpful :

✳️Create role with just 1 transaction - BP in it. Infact you can have multiple versions of such roles with various degree of access to the single BP transaction. These roles then can be incorporated into Composite roles for better administration. Your roles will look something like this:

  • ZBP_VENDOR - BP role with access to only Vendor(Supplier) Master Data
  • ZBP_CUSTOMER - BP role with access to only Customer Master Data
  • ZBP_MASTERDATA_ALL - BP role with Full access to both Customers & Vendors
  • ZBP_DISPLAY_ALL - BP role with Display all access

You can follow this helpful guide for role creation - Business Partner Authorization Tips and Tricks

✳️In SU24, you can set the check indicator for unused authorization objects linked to the BP transaction to "No". For rarely used authorization objects, setting them to "Yes, Inactive Default" helps keep things tidy. This simple step significantly reduces clutter and simplifies role maintenance.

✳️When troubleshooting, start by checking the user buffer using transaction SU56. If the user has multiple single roles assigned, they might be receiving access to the relevant authorization object from one of these roles—effectively bypassing the intended restrictions on the BP transaction.

✳️Ensure that the authorization object is included in the user's profile—this is especially important for optional objects like B_BUPA_FDG, which can be used to restrict access to specific fields within the BP transaction. If this object is not included in the user's role, or if it exists in an inactive state. The system will ignore the restrictions, and the user will have unrestricted access to the field. The system only enforces restrictions if the object is present and active in the user master record.

✳️Although rare, there are cases where the SAP system may not behave as expected or fail to respect certain authorization checks—potentially due to a system issue on SAP’s end. We encountered such a scenario where the system was incorrectly checking for activity "05" (Block) on F_LFA1_GRP objects even when simply displaying a Business Partner. SAP acknowledged the issue and provided a correction through an OSS Notes. https://me.sap.com/notes/3097438/E , https://me.sap.com/notes/3093933/E

✳️For handling complex scenarios or implementing custom logic, you can collaborate with your functional and development teams to explore available BADIs or customer exits that may be leveraged. Refer to the resources below to explore such solutions in more detail:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKlshC0uyyE
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/0002606686
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/2309153

entry.title: SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Q2 2025 - What's New?
entry.content:
Q2 2025 has been an exciting quarter for SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, bringing a rich set of innovations that simplify asset management, enhance data usability, and strengthen collaboration between asset operators, OEMs and service providers. This quarter focuses on advancing master data management, improving work order processes, and expanding integration and API capabilities to support seamless and standardized operations. Whether you're managing material data, processing equipment entry, or working with shared notifications and work orders, these updates are designed to help you work smarter, faster, and more collaboratively across your asset ecosystem.

 

Material Outbound Integration

Scope:

  • Support ERP outbound replication of materials to models between SAP ERP and SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

Key Benefits:

  • As an asset operator, you can replicate components assigned to work orders and work order operations from SAP ERP to SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. Consequently, you can share the work order operations with the corresponding components to an external service providers so that the service providers has a complete overview on the work to be performed and the required spare parts.

Description:

  • This feature allows you to perform outbound sync of material data from ERP to models in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. The associated material classes, characteristics, characteristic values, and documents are replicated as model templates, attributes, data sheet, and associated documents for the model.

    For more information, see Materials.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Assignment of Components to Work Orders and Work Order Operations

Scope:

  • Assignment of Components for Work Orders & Work Order Operations

Key Benefits:

  • Enable customers to replicate ERP materials to SAB Business Network Asset Collaboration models
  • Component suppliers and product manufacturers can leverage this feature to share technical information about their spare parts and products with SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, starting from the corresponding existing materials in SAP ERP
  • Asset Operators can leverage this feature to share spare parts (i.e. components) associated to specific work orders and work order operations to external contractors, starting from the corresponding work orders and work order operations in SAP ERP (i.e. SAP Plant Maintenance)

Description:

  • For work orders and work order operations, you can now see a new tab called Components. Here, you can view the list of attached components and their related information. You can also share this list of components with your external contractors.

For more information, see Viewing a Work Order and Viewing the Operations to be performed for a Work Order.

 

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Models (i.e. Types)

Scope:

  • You can now upload single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of model entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating the AAS-standardized submodel “Handover Documentation” efficiently.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate model creation with documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the model and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting model and associated documents in the Model application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Attribute-based Search for Documents

Scope:

  • Provide the ability to search and filter documents based on document attribute values

Key Benefits:

  • Find and filter the right documents based on attribute values
  • Consume document standards and corresponding attributes in daily business processes

Description:

  • You can now search for documents using the search field.

  • As part of the document search, you can filter the documents . A new filter option based on the document template is also available .

  • Attribute based search is also enabled.

 

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Equipment

Scope:

  • The new feature allows you to upload a single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of equipment entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating AAS - standardized Submodels Digital Nameplate and Handover Documentation data efficiently, making it more user-friendly.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate equipment creation with digital nameplate and documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Integrate with SAP Plant Maintenance for smooth synchronization of digital twin data with existing maintenance processes, which helps ensure that the latest equipment data, along with its associated documentation, is readily available for maintenance teams
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the equipment, digital nameplate, and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting equipment, digital nameplate, and associated documents in the Equipment application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

Other Innovations

  • Header PATCH API for equipment
    • This feature allows you to update values for header fields of the specified equipment using the PATCH API. For more information, see Equipment API.
  • Specify values for components in model structure
    • This feature allows you to assign and maintain quantity values for each component in the model structure. The model record creation now supports the assignment of precise quantity or quantity range with decimal values based on the base Unit of Measure (UoM) of the assigned component, if the base UoM is different than Each and Piece. For more information, see Creating a Model.
  • Templates for notifications
    • You can now add templates to notifications to maintain and share attributes related to the notification. For more information, see Creating a Notification.
    • The APIs are enhanced for the same. For more information, see Notifications API.
  • New APIs for work orders
    • GET API available to retrieve a list of templates associated with a work order.
    • PUT API available to modify attribute value in a work order.
    • For more information, see Work Orders - API.
  • Notification enhancements
    • As a service provider, you can view the shared status of the notification in the list page. For more information, see Sharing a Notification.
    • You can edit the priority of notifications as long as they are not shared or synchronized with the ERP system. For more information, see Creating a Notification.

Upcoming Innovations

Following exciting innovations are planned for the upcoming major release of SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration:

  • Header PATCH APIs for functional locations
  • Representing and sharing product families and configurations
  • Integration of ERP Materials to BNAC Models (brownfield/mapping)
  • Enablement of advanced search for technical objects on Azure
  • Public GET & POST APIs for Work Order-Operation - Collaboration Statuses
  • Collaborative statuses for notifications
  • Asset Administration Shell REST APIs
  • Etc.

Submit innovation requests

We encourage you to visit the SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Customer Influence Portal to submit your innovation requests and review and vote innovation requests submitted by other customers.

entry.title: Re: Change Master Template for PO Print with Adobe Designer
entry.content:
Hello @Dylan2 ,

Great to hear the company name is working!

For the legal provisions, the best approach is to create a new master page in Adobe LiveCycle Designer (Legal_Provisions) and leave “Place at Start” and “Place at End” unchecked. Then, use a subform that’s only shown when needed.
Just ensure the subform allows page breaks and isn’t placed inside a static container that blocks it.

If you like a reference or walkthrough, here are a few helpful SAP links.

SAP Learning Hub – Using Master Pages and Design Views

SAP Community – Creating New Master Page

With kind regards

Chuma
